hints_html:
In the steady state of an ODE, the derivative equals \(0\). Hence solve the equation

\(0 = I - \alpha N F\)

for \(F\).

The solution \(F\) of the equation is

\(F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})\)
hints_latex:
In the steady state of an ODE, the derivative equals $0$. Hence solve
the equation

$0 = I - \alpha N F$

for $F$.

The solution $F$ of the equation is

$F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})$
hints_raw:
In the steady state of an ODE, the derivative equals <math>0</math>. Hence solve the equation

<math> 0 = I - \alpha N F</math>

for <math> F</math>.
The solution <math> F</math> of the equation is

<math> F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})</math>
question: C 02 (c)
sols_html:
• In the steady state, the derivative is equal to \(0\). Hence we solve the equation

\(I - \alpha N F\) for \(F\) and obtain

\(F_* = \frac{I}{N\alpha}\)

  • The solution \(F\) of the equation is

\(F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})\)

In order to find \(t_*\), where \(F(t_*) = \frac{F_*}{2}\), we set

\(\frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha Nt_*})\)

and use that \(\frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{2\alpha N}\) to find

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{I}{2\alpha N} = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t_*})\quad\Rightarrow\quad \frac12 = e^{-\alpha Nt_*} \quad\Rightarrow\quad \ln(\frac12) = -\alpha Nt_*\end{aligned}\]

Now we solve for \(t_* = -\frac{\ln(\frac12)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{\ln(1) - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{0 - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = \frac{\ln(2)}{\alpha N}\)
sols_latex:
\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  In the steady state, the derivative is equal to $0$. Hence we solve
  the equation
\end{itemize}

$I - \alpha N F$ for $F$ and obtain

$F_* = \frac{I}{N\alpha}$

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The solution $F$ of the equation is
\end{itemize}

$F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})$

In order to find $t_*$, where $F(t_*) = \frac{F_*}{2}$, we set

$\frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha Nt_*})$

and use that $\frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{2\alpha N}$ to find

\begin{align*}
\frac{I}{2\alpha N} = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t_*})\quad\Rightarrow\quad
 \frac12 = e^{-\alpha Nt_*} \quad\Rightarrow\quad
 \ln(\frac12) = -\alpha Nt_*
\end{align*}

Now we solve for
$t_* = -\frac{\ln(\frac12)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{\ln(1) - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{0 - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = \frac{\ln(2)}{\alpha N}$

<math> F(t) = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha N t})</math> 

In order to find <math> t_*</math>, 
where <math>F(t_*) = \frac{F_*}{2}</math>, we set


<math> \frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{\alpha N}(1-e^{-\alpha Nt_*})</math>

and use that <math> \frac{F_*}{2} = \frac{I}{2\alpha N}</math> to find

 \frac12 = e^{-\alpha Nt_*} \quad\Rightarrow\quad
 \ln(\frac12) = -\alpha Nt_*
\end{align}</math>

Now we solve for <math> t_* = -\frac{\ln(\frac12)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{\ln(1) - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = -\frac{0 - \ln(2)}{\alpha N} = \frac{\ln(2)}{\alpha N}</math>
statement_html:
The population of fish in a particular lake is given by the function F(t) where F is measured in number of fish and t is measured in days. A company that manages fish stocks is hired to restock the lake, adding fish at a constant rate. Only N fishers are allowed to fish in the lake at a time. A simple model for this scenario is given by the equation:

\(\frac{dF}{dt} = I - \alpha N F\)

Where I and \(\alpha\) are constant and two cases for N are considered.

Case 1: Suppose N is a constant. What is the steady state number of fish \((F_*)\) in the lake? If the lake has no fish in it initially, at what time \((t_*)\) does the population size reach half its steady state value \(F_*/2\)? (You do not have to show a derivation of the solution F(t) of the equation for full points - simply stating it is sufficient - but you must show the rest of the calculation.)
statement_latex:
The population of fish in a particular lake is given by the function
\emph{F(t)} where \emph{F} is measured in number of fish and \emph{t} is
measured in days. A company that manages fish stocks is hired to restock
the lake, adding fish at a constant rate. Only \emph{N} fishers are
allowed to fish in the lake at a time. A simple model for this scenario
is given by the equation:

$\frac{dF}{dt} = I - \alpha N F$

Where \emph{I} and $\alpha$ are constant and two cases for \emph{N} are
considered.

Case 1: Suppose \emph{N} is a constant. What is the steady state number
of fish $(F_*)$ in the lake? If the lake has no fish in it initially, at
what time $(t_*)$ does the population size reach half its steady state
value $F_*/2$? (You do not have to show a derivation of the solution
\emph{F(t)} of the equation for full points - simply stating it is
sufficient - but you must show the rest of the calculation.)
statement_raw:
The population of fish in a particular lake is given by the function ''F(t)'' where ''F'' is measured in number of fish and ''t'' is measured in days.  A company that manages fish stocks is hired to restock the lake, adding fish at a constant rate.  Only ''N'' fishers are allowed to fish in the lake at a time.  A simple model for this scenario is given by the equation: 

<math>\frac{dF}{dt} = I - \alpha N F </math>

Where ''I'' and <math>\alpha</math> are constant and two cases for ''N'' are considered.  

Case 1: Suppose ''N'' is a constant.  What is the steady state number of fish <math>(F_*)</math> in the lake?  If the lake has no fish in it initially, at what time <math>(t_*)</math> does the population size reach half its steady state value <math>F_*/2</math>?  (You do not have to show a derivation of the solution ''F(t)'' of the equation for full points - simply stating it is sufficient - but you must show the rest of the calculation.)
